note.p: Birth: Derbyshire, England (01 May 1665)
Death: At his apartments in Gresham College, London (25 April 1728)
Burial: Westminster Abbey
Profession: Physician
Research Field: Geology; Botany, Antiquarianism
Education: Apprenticed to a linen draper; pupil of Peter Barwick FCP; MD (Lambeth 1695); incorporated at Cambridge

Career: Gresham Professor of Physic (1692-death); possibly the inspiration for the caricature of the 'virtuoso' in Judith Drake's 'An essay in defence of the female sex' (1696); Expelled from the Royal Society for insulting Sir Hans Sloane with the words "speak sense or English and we shall understand you. If you understood anatomy you would know better" (Council Minutes, 29 March 1710) whilst Sloane was reading a paper before the Society. Woodward refused to make the required apology (Council Minutes 24 May 1710) and was expelled from the Council and the Society; he brought an action against the Royal Society Council (Council Minutes, 17 June 1710) but lost. He was involved in a sword fight with Richard Mead (FRS 1703) in Gresham College (1719); died of a decline; benefactor to the University of Cambridge, his collection of fossils formed the nucleus of the Woodwardian Museum
Memberships: FCP (1702/3)
Membership: Fellow
Election Date: 30/11/1693
Proposers: Robert Hooke
Council: 1696, 1698
Expelled from the Society's Council 1710
